In chapters 17 and 18 Huck sees the spiraling and meaningless destructiveness of a family feud and the murder of a boy of his age with whom he had become friendly. Huck says about this murder, “I ain't agoing to tellallthat happened—it would make me sick again if I was to do that” ( Twain , Adventures of Huckleberry Finn ,121). In chapter 19 Huck and Jim fall into the company of two frauds who involve Huck in all kinds of shenanigans; over chapters 24 through 29, the frauds embroil Huck in deceit that he comes to find “disgusting” and “sickening” but can for some while “see no safe way … to chip in” and break out of (170,187; see also180). In chapter 21, for good measure, Huck sees the murder of a harmless town drunk in the very sight of his daughter (149). In chapter 22 Huck sees a lynch mob gather to string up the murderer, only to scatter when he defies it to try (152–53).

After seeing the murder of his friend, Huck searches for Jim, who when he sees Huck
“grabbed me and hugged me, he was so glad to see me”(ibid.,122). Huck is likewise glad to see Jim—Huck says in this moment, “nothing ever sounded so good” as the sound of Jim's voice—and once they are back on the river they agree that“there warn't no home like a raft, after all”(123). On the raft “we dangled our legs in the water and talked about all kinds of things,” most “always naked” with one another, with nothing to hide (125). Huck also notes that Jim often took his watch at night: “he was always mighty good that way, Jim was” (134); “[h]e often done that” (161). It also seems that Huck is aware of how remarkable it is that Jim is accompanying him farther down the river—farther and farther south, and so farther and farther from the free states (132). It does not seem to occur to Huck, though, that Jim is staying with him to care for him; Huck seems to think that he is taking care of Jim (131).

In trying finally to escape the two frauds, Huck tells a young woman whom the men are deceiving that “if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, andI'd be all right, but there'd be another person that you don't know about who'd be in big trouble” (ibid.,193). This “person” is Jim. Whether Huck would otherwise call Jim a person, but for the fact that it can't be revealed that he's black, is unclear. What is clear here is that, as Jim's friend, Huck takes Jim's good as his own good and, for Jim's sake, makes matters more difficult for himself than they need be. In Aristotle's terms, Huck cares for Jim as “another self.”
Huck comments at one point, “I do believe [Jim] cared just as much for his people as white folks does for their'n. It don't seem natural, but I reckon it's so” (ibid.,161).

Kant presents the judgments of conscience as “determinant” judgments, subsuming a particular under a given universal; see part 2 of The Metaphysics of Morals, Metaphysical Principles of the Doctrine of Virtue , §13,6:438. Spaemann follows Kant in characterizing conscience as“a faculty of subsuming cases under rules”( Persons ,172).

For example, in speaking of conscience as “a principle planted within us, before we had any training, although training and experience are necessary for its strength, growth, and due formation,” Newman echoes the scholastic account of conscience, which considered it a disposition of practical reason, calledsynderesis, consisting in the understanding of the principles of morality; the termconscientiawas reserved for the act of application of these principles.Synderesis, as natural knowledge, was considered infallible, though as Newman indicates subject to the vagaries of a person's training and experience;conscientiawas considered fallible, as it was acknowledged that the application of the principles of morality could go wrong, whether because the person did not adequately grasp these principles (a possibility in a corrupt society) or because the person erred in his or her construal of the situation to which they were to be applied. See Aquinas , ST I, q. 79, a. 12 and 13. See Donagan , The Theory of Morality ,132, for the difference between Newman and Aquinas.
Heidegger's account of conscience is found in §§54–60 ofBeing and Time. See for penetrating discussion Dahlstrom ,“Conscience: The Lonely Discourse.”
